title: Finding an Expected Count for GOF Test
question_text:
The Advanced Placement (AP) Statistics examination is administered each year in May. Students’ papers are graded on a scale of $1$ – $5$, with $5$ being the highest score. In $2016$, over $200{,}000$ students took the exam and the distribution of their scores is displayed in the table below.
The teacher at a local high school had $108$ of her AP Statistics students take the exam in May of $2016$ .
Which of the following is the expected count for a score of $5$?
tables:
Score$1$$2$$3$$4$$5$
Percent$24$%$15.7$%$24.7$%$21.7$%$13.9$%
solution:
Solution

To calculate the expected value in a one-way table, use the formula:

$$\text {expected value} = (\text {sample size})(\text {population proportion})$$

For an AP Exam score of a $5$, the expected value = $108$ $\text{ x }$ $13.9$% = $15.012$

So, Choice 'E' is correct.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice ‘A’ is incorrect: $13.9$ is the percent of the population that earned a $5$ on the exam in $2016$.

Choice ‘B’ is incorrect: $5$ is the correct value for the degrees of freedom for this setting. In a one-way table, $ \text {degrees of freedom} = (\text {number of categories}) - 1$

Choice ‘C’ is incorrect: $108$ is the sample size taken for the study.

Choice ‘D’ is incorrect: $27800$ is the value that results when multiplying the population size of $200000$ by the population proportion of $13.9$%.
